paper.title: Computationally convincing proofs of knowledge
paper.venue: Symposium on Theoretical Aspects of Computer Science
paper.abstract: The original definition of interactive proof-systems, as given by Goldwasser, Micali and Rackoff, does not impose limits on the proveru0027s computing power [GMR89]. This is also the case for Babaiu0027s Arthur-Merlin games IBM88]. Hence, the prover may wish to convince the verifier of the t ru th of an assertion, but it does not really make sense for the prover to convince the verifier that she 1 knows a proof of the assertion (of course she knows such a proof if it exists since she is all-powerful). Nevertheless, Feige, Fiat and Shamir [FFS88], and Tompa and Woll [TW87] have given formal definitions of what should constitute a proof of knowledge in the context of interactive proof-systems.
